Speaker: Mr MCNEILL
Title: Unknown
text: Wannon) [1.30 a.m.] The defence question is one which affects every man, woman, and child in this country. I agree with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Charlton) that the time has arrived when there should be a re-organization of our policy of defence, and it should take place in Australia, and nob at the Imperial Conference. England expects that the people of Australia will shape and maintain their own defence policy, and that is the common sense vi-jw to take of the matter. The fact that the military arm of our Defence Force is to cost, roughly, £38,000 more this year than last year, indicates one direction in which we can economize, and there are many in which we might, economize without endangering the safety of the country. I am one whobelieves bhat we should launch out in the building of submarines and aeroplanes, and certainly we should proceed with the manufacture in this country of arms and ammunition. It would be of very little use for us to attempt to defend this country were an invader to land here if we had not arms and ammunition. It must be clear to every honourable member that if this country is invaded within the next year or two the war will be fought, not on land, but in the air and on the sea. Laboratories throughout the world are today staffed* with the best scientists, who are endeavouring to discover the most deadly weapon that could be used in the way of poison gas. Future hostile operations- I will not speak of them as warfare, but as cold-blooded inurderwill be conducted from the air, and whole nations may be destroyed with poison gas. We are doing nothing in this direction, and we are doing nothing in the direction of manufacturing big guns, arms, and ammunition. I think it was the honourable member for Corio (Mr Lister) who said that the guns in our fortifications have a range of not more than 5 or 6 miles. They are practically obsolete. It is our duty to see that our forts are armed with up-to-date guns. In addition, we should proceed with the building of aeroplanes and submarines. I am not a military expert/, of course, but my bush instincts me to believe that if Australia were well supplied with an air fleet and submarines, and our forts were armed with the biggest guns that could be procured, we should be pretty safe from any attack. Eor the last thirty years we have been hearing from ' the press and from prominent citizens that it is only a matter of a year or two before Japan will attack us. Japan has not attacked us so far, and I see no indication that she is going to attack us. I am one of those who believe that we shall never quarrel with Japan.

I say that such a thing is beyond the bounds of possibility. If there is an invasion of Australia, without a doubt it will be from the air. We have been told by many of the experts during the last twelve months that great scientists have been at work, and that America, France, and also Great Britain are in a position to manufacture some of the - most deadly gases that it is possible for the mind of man to conceive. If that is so, we should be taking action in that direction. If it is a good thing for other nations to set scientists to work to devise the deadly weapon of poison gas, we should do the same. If a nation hostile to Australia has a supply of deadly gases with which to destroy this country, where shall we be? Most honourable members opposite are fair minded men, and I confess that I was astounded at the remarks of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr R. Green). He made the charge against the Labour party that it is anti-Australian. I am an Australian born. I say that Australia is the best country in the world, and I want to live in no other country. I suppose I had as many relatives fighting in the war as the honourable member, who. unfortunately, lost a leg, for which I am very sorry. His remarks were absolutely uncalled for, and they will not assist the Government or the Opposition to frame a policy for the defence of this country. If we are not all Australian-born we are Australians by adoption. I will not abuse any honourable member on the other side because he holds views on defence which are different from mine. I respect every man's. opinion. I am president of the Labour party in Victoria, and it is one of the greatest parties in this young country. The Labour party of England is one of the greatest parties in Great Britain today. There are in that party some of the finest intellects in the British Empire. Will the honourable member for Richmond say that the gentlemen who form the Labour party in the House of Commons are antiBritish? He would not bo game to say that. If he would not be game to attack the British Labour party as being antiBritish he has no right to come here and say that the Australian Labour party is anti-Australian.

Speaker: Mr LISTEK
Title: Unknown
text: I do not think the honourable member is quite fair. The honourable member for Richmond did not say that the Australian Labour party was anti-Australian; he said that it has pandered' to people who are anti-Australian.

Speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN
Title: Unknown
text: As the honourable member for Richmond withdrew the remarks to which exception was taken, they cannot now be referred to.

Speaker: Mr MCNEILL
Title: Unknown
text: I should think that the honourable member would withdraw those remarks. He should go further, aud apologize for them. I remember that when Mr Andrew Fisher was Leader of the Labour party in Australia, the Tories of those days proposed to make a present of a Dreadnought to Great Britain. They considered that that was the way in which we should take our share in the defence of Australia. Mr Fisher and his party, in 1910, said, " No. Australia is going to be defended in a proper way, and Australia will build its own Navy." We did so. The men who pretended in those days that they were the true blues, the only pebbles on the beach, were the men who laughed at the proposal of the Labour party for the building of an Australian Navy. I remember that Sir Joseph Cook, the present High Commissioner, referred to the Australian Fleet as a "Mosquito Fleet." It is a most remarkable thing that, later, it was one of Australia's vessels that destroyed the Emden, the enemy ship that no other ships could capture. The Labour party is given no credit for that. This party has played a clean and honest game, aud has pursued a clean and honest course so far as the defence of this country and the welfare of Australia is concerned. will do so until its last man is dead. It is, therefore, quite uncalled for that honourable member should get up here, and say that we are anti-Australian, and that we sheltered the cold-footers. We did nothing of the kind. I know to what the honourable member was referring. He was referring to the fact that the Australian Labour party opposed conscription, the defeat of which enabled the men whom he called " cold-footers" to escape military service. If there is one thing of which I am. proud it is that the Australian people defeated conscription on two occasions, and while there is breath in my body I shall resist compulsory military service. Australia should be kept free of the military discipline that is imposed unfairly upon the men of older countries. Those who have been at the war know that any soldier in Englr.nd, France, or America who dared to protest against the tyranny of some petty officer was gaoled, whilst pacifists were treated worse than criminals. We do not desire that sort of thing to occur in Australia-it does not fit in with the democratic ideas of our people. Give the Australians a fair and honest chance and they are the best people in the world. No finer body of men ever donned a uniform than the Australians who went to the war. Those who say that men cannot be trained for active service in a few months do not know what they are talking about. The men who lefit Australia spent some weeks on the water, a little time in Egypt, and then were rushed to Gallipoli, where undoubtedly they were badly handled. They were thrown into a hell compared with which the charge at Balaclava was insignificant, yet they accomplished their task as only Australians could.

Speaker: Mr LISTER
Title: Unknown
text: Thos e men had had four months training in Egypt in addition to the training they received in camp in Australia.

Speaker: Mr MCNEILL
Title: Unknown
text: I admit that; but if they had been trained in camp for four years they would not have been any better than they were after four months. I do not think there are any Australians who are not. prepared to defend their country, but we on this side of the It Chamber recognise that the Commonwealth has a debt of almost any £1,000,000,000, and we should therefore cut down defence expenditure as far as may be consistent with safety. We cannot continue piling up millions of pounds of debt; we must call a halt at some time. It may be possible to save a few hundred thousands of pounds in the Defence and other Departments of the Estimates. We have responsibility on our shoulders for steering the ship of State to a haven of safety, and the suggestion made by the Leader of the Opposition that we should re-organize ourDefence policy is sound. If the Government cannot do that this year, they should, at least, take into consideration the advisability of doing it next year, so that we may get the most effective defence at a minimum cost.

Speaker: Mr MARRS
Title: Unknown
text: Wentworth) [1.55 a.m.]. - In two rather long speeches, which I made earlier in the session, I expressed my views regarding the A i r Force and the Navy, and I shall not dwell upon tliose subjects this morning; The Leader of the Oppositionasked what form Australian defence should take. I understand that the Imperial Conference will advise Australia upon that matter, and until we hear from the Conference, through the Prime Minister on his return, we can do nothing but tread water. Treading water is costing us a lot of money; but I do not see how we can avoid that. We have a large - personnel, wages are high, and the cost of food is very great Those three facts largely account for the amount appearing in the Defence Estimates. The '' man in the street" wants to know what Australia is getting for the expenditure. The answer is> "Not much, beyond a highly efficient personnel." That is the opinion of the Admiral and others who can speak with authority regarding the Royal Australian Navy. Australia is to be congratulated upon having a man like Colonel Brinsmead in charge of civil aviation, and the Government are deserving of thanks for having placed on the Estimates a sum of about $60,000 to subsidize aviation. I am in favour of using commercial air pilots for defence if they can hove an intensive course of defence training before going on to the air routes, and come back periodically for refresher courses. Airmen who had not had intensive training would not be of much use for defence purposes. From time to time. I have placed upon the notice-paper questions regarding naval affairs, and the reply in every instance was far from satisfactory. I have received dozens of answers, and nearly all sidestepped the questions. The Minister i» perfectly innocent of any intention to deceive, but honourable members will recollect the Gunner Yates' incident, in connection with which Sir Granville Ryrie explained that he had been " sold a pup " by somebody in his Department. I warn Ministers to be careful or otherwise they, too, will be " sold a pup." The replies they have given in the House were not honest, and it is time that some member protested. For instance, I asked the Prime Minister, first without notice, and later upon notice, whether the Commonwealth would follow the - lead of the British Government in subscribing towards the great Victory fund for. repairing Nelson's old flagship? The reply I received was that the fund was' being raised by public subscription, and that the British Government was doing nothing to help it. Everybody who takes an interest in the matter knows perfectly well that the Admiralty subscribed £25,000 towardsthe fund; yet the Prime Minister was told by his Naval Adviser that the British Government is not doing anything in that regard. That is one instance of an unsatisfactory reply to a question. Here is another: I asked the TreasurerWhether the Government will consider the advisability of collecting Federal taxation from officers and ratings in the Royal Australian Navy, as is done in the Royal Navy, by the necessary deductions being made in the ship's ledgers, and paid to the Taxation Department by the Naval Board, the accountant officers of the ships being responsible for such deductions ? That is a very simple way of collecting this taxation. The reply I received was-*Yes.' There is, however; nothing to indicate that this course would be agreeable to the taxpayers concerned, and there certainly has been ho demand from them for the intervention of the Naval accountant officers in the manner suggested. Yet, in 1922, the Welfare Committee, composed of officers and men, and appointed to consider all grievances in the Navy, specifically asked that this course should be followed. I could relate a dozen other illustrations, all of which occurred within the last two or three weeks, of equally unsatisfactory answers, and I could name the man who writes the replies for the Minister. I am fed up with this sort of thing. I am giving this warning to Ministers because if they are not careful they will fall in. What is the use of an honourable member asking questions if he is not to receive honest answers? I have almost discontinued asking questions, because the replies I have been getting have not been fair'. I asked some time ago whether it was a fact that recruiting for the Navy was slackening. The reply was, " Yes. But recruiting shows signs of improvement.** On the Estimates is a sum of £41,000 for the transhipment of bluejackets from England to Australia, whilst the cost of maintaining the training ship Tingira .is £60,000 per annum. Why cannot we recruit men in Australia? Because the Department does not go the right way about it . Why not institute a more vigorous method of recruiting, and emulate the British system of displaying on railway stations and book-stalls handsome illuminated posters, showing the white ensign, where they would attract ths notice of lads who wanted to go to sea and fire their imagination. There is plenty of material in Australia from which to recruit the naval ratings, for love of the sea is inbred in the British race. I receive many letters from time to time from retired Royal Navy ratings who during a long term of service have become skilled as turret officers, submarine experts, fire control officers, and so on. They have had to retire at the age of thirty-nine years and are living in Melbourne, Sydney, and other capital cities, upon small pensions. They are dying to get to sea for a fortnight or longer every year, but, so far as I can ascertain, there is no means by which they can be kept up to the mark in the respective branches in which they have made themselves skilful, so that they may be ready when called up by Order in Council upon the outbreak of hostilities. There should be some means of allowing these men to go off to sea and keep up-todate in their special branches. I can understand the reason for protests by honourable members opposite at the limitation of the time available for the discussion of these Estimates. I have a great quantity of material of much' interest to honourable members, but I cannot make use of it because my time is all too short. On 3rd March last I asked the Minister if , against the event of ths in mobilization of the Australian Citizen Naval Forces, adequate - stocks of uniforms and accoutrements were held in reserve; and if , against the event of hostilities breaking out, complete sets of all stores were held in readiness for immediate supply to the ships. The official reply wasReasonable stocks are held in reserve and no difficulty is anticipated in obtaining supplies. I should like to know what is meant by the term " reasonable" stocks. If events developed as rapidly as in 1914, could all the reserve be fully equipped immediately ? In view of the disposal of the Geelong Woollen Mill, and the closing-down of other Government factories, what about uniforms and accoutrements ? It is well known to everybody that reasonable stocks are not in store and available for our Forces in the event of an outbreak of hostilities. Then, again, I asked the Minister, for Trade and Customs whether the long-established custom in the Royal Navy of selling tobacco duty free to officers and ratings could not be followed in the Royal Australian Navy, and under the same rules and restrictions as apply in the Royal Navy. The Minister's reply to that question was to this effectThere is no power to remit duty payable on goqda consumed in Australian waters. Could not the Government provide the necessary power required, as this provision is more closely related to the general contentment in a sailor's life than is, perhaps, understood by people on shore. This, too, was the subject of a " welfare " request in 1922. I asked the Minister whether under regulation No. 12, men compulsorily retired from sea-going duty on account of age and invalidity and not absorbed in auxiliary services, would be given preference in civil employment, and whether the regulation was still in. force. The Minister's reply was: " This is not a regulation, but an instruction." Well, I have here the book- " Royal Australian Navy-Permanent . Naval Forces-, Sea-going," and in it is " regulation" No. 12, dealing with engagement, promotion and retirement of men. Where is this going to end ? I now direct the attention of the Minister to the position of the Army Instructional Corps. There is general dissatisfaction among the men regard to living allowances. In the Public Service married men 'of get a living allowance of £ 1 a week, ducts should be encouraged. with an additional 5s. for each child. the Defence Department the allowance only 10s., and 3s. 6d. for each child. This matter should be looked into. have had conversations with Ministers this subject, and they admit that the request of the men for better 'treatment isreasonable. The men in the Army Instructional Corps discharge important duties in the training of our citizen troops; and I assure the Minister that they are very, dissatisfied. I trust, thereting fore, that he will look into the question. I know it is a matter of finance, but possible this discontent in the Service should be removed. I warn the Ministheir ter to give serious consideration to the questions I have raised, otherwise get " landed " just as General Ryrie " landed." Mr C. text: Adelaide) [4 a.m.] - I think that by this time the Government must realise the harm they are doing to the country by l i m it i ng the debate on the Estimates in the way they have done. I wish especially to deal with the regulation issued by the Minister for Trade and Customs imposing restrictions on the exportation of the fauna of Australia. I am inclined to think that the Department is not full y seized of the harm which this - regulation is doing. If the M in ister will go into the matter further he will realise this. In proof of my statement. I propose to read some correspondence which passed between myself and the Minister on this matter. the 29 th March there was published in the Commonwealth Gazette, No. 23, a regulation prohibiting the exportation of certain birds. It was noted by b i r d dealers in South Australia, and I was approached by them. They are not very numerous, because as honourable members are aware, their's is not a very flourishing business. The regulation imposes very great hardship upon those engaged in that business. I have not very much knowledge of the . birds of Australia, .but I believe that the restrictions placed upon their export are more drastic than they need be. I received a letter from a bird dealer in ' Adelaide on the subject, and I interviewed the inspector of game and fisheries in South Australia. I want to make it clear to the Minister that the exportation of game and birds from South Australia is regulated by the Game and Fisheries Act of that State. I have not only seen the inspectorof game and fisheries, but have had conversations with a son of the curator of the Adelaide Zoological Gardens. This gentleman is honorary zoologist to the London Zoological Museum, and has gone I to the Old Country. The Minister will realise from the information I am in a position to give that the opposition to the regulation is not merely a factious opposition. "When the regulation was promulgated, the bird dealer to whom I refer wrote to me, and I forwarded extracts from his letter to the Minister in the following terms:12th June, 1923. Hon. Austin Chapman, M.H.R., Minister for Customs. Dear Sir, I desire to bring under your notice what is urged to be an injustice entailed upon the dealers in birds, &c., by the Proclamation No. 75, published in the Commonwealth Gazette, No. 23, of 29th March '.ast, having relation to the export of birds. In doing so it would, perhaps, be best for me to quote you a letter I have received on the subject from one of the largest exporters of birds in South Australia:" This proclamation prohibits the export of a large number of birds on the unprotected list in this State, which we in the past have been able to export. " AH birds and animals exported by me are forwarded under permit issued by the Minister of Industry. The Chief Inspector of Fisheries and Game also personally inspects all birds and accommodation provided for them at the time of shipment, and his approval, is necessary before they ore allowed to leave. " I have on hand at present £200 worth of On fresh material for making cages for export trade, and nearly £100 worth of new, thoroughly, clean, and disinfected boxes ready for next season's shipment. " On all my shipments I accompany the birds to the place of destination, and an attendant is also engaged. A limited number only are put iuto each cage, and are well looked after, the mortality amongst them being practically nil. I also import and accompany birds from South Africa and other places under the same conditions. Mr Seth Smith, of the London Zoo, was greatly impressed with the conditions under which my birds travel and the health in which they are, landed. The London press has also favourably commented on all of my shipments. " I have orders MI hand now for the shipment of birds in the coming season for the London Zoo, and if I cannot export them my loss will be a severe one. I trust that, in view of the above facts, you will place this matter before the Minister on my behalf,- pointing out to him how harshly this proclamation will affect genuine dealers desiring to carry on a botiu fide business in this direction, and request that I be allowed to continue my shipments of birds under permit and inspection as in the past. I am dependent on this business for my living, and if the proclamation is adhered to, my living wili be taken away and my trade ruined. " Might I also point out that thousands upon thousands of ducks and quail are shot and killed annually in Australia, and yet the proclamation will not allow live birds to be exported. Many of the birds covered by the proclamation have been proved to be terribly destructive on farms, orchards, &c." I have also been interviewed by others interested in the export of animals and birds, and the consensus of opinion is that the objected to proclamation will do untold harm. The stationinaster at Ivimba, on the west coast of South Australia, avers:- " There arc thousands of Ring Neck Parrots (Pt. Lincoln); they do great damage to the wheat in stacks and on trucks, boring boles, in the bags, and in consequence a lot of wheat is lost between here - and Pt. Lincoln." Mr Minchin, who is proceeding to London Jia Honorary Curator to the London Zoological Gardens, states :- " My experience is that the Blue Mountain and Pt. Lincoln Ring Neck Parrot infest the whole of the west coast, and docs great damage to the fruit crops, and is a groat trouble to the new settlers in those areas. The Chief Inspector of Fisheries and Game in Melbourne informed me that when he was here in April last, he was surprised to find how numerous and destructive the Pt. Lincoln parrots w*re on fruit, &c, also the Blue Mountain parrot on fruit. As an example, at the Government Forest all fruit is bagged on the trees to protect it. Many farmers said they were partially protected, and asked me to let the authorities know that they rivalled the - Ttogella in destruotiveness." He also veferred me to letters sent by Mr L. R. Scainniell to Mr. Rodgers, late Minister for Customs, on the 17th October, 1922, and Mr A. G. Rymill on the 27th September, 1922. I would esteem it a favour if you would have these letters brought before you, and give consideration to the matters contained herein.

text: Kooyong) [4.17 a.m.J. - The ' honourable member for Adelaide has raised an important question. It is desired to prevent cruelty in the export of birds and animals, because other animals than birds are. covered by the regulation. The State authorities have no power to control the export of anything, but in most States make provision for the protection of birds and other animals against cruelty. It may be, as the honourable member for Adelaide has said, that conditions are all that could be desired in South Australia, but the matter has to be looked at generally. Recent experience has shown that further precautions than those adopted in at least some States are required, and there is, therefore, good i ground for Commonwealth interference in the matter. Another aspect of the subject is that Australia is being denuded of certain rare birds and animals. Not long ago four birds were seen in New South Wales not far from Sydney, which had not been seen in the vicinity for about twenty years. Their discovery was reported in one of the bird journals. No more was heard of them until it was known that two birds of the species had appeared in New York. Surely that kind of thing shows the need for rigid control. Some of our animals are very rare,- and scientists say that some may hold secrets which may be of the very greatest value to humanity. One name mentioned by the honourable member for Adelaide was that of Dr Colin Mackenzie, who has conducted extensive researches relating to Australian animals. He is my authority for the statement that a great contribution, may be made to science and human well-being by a proper study of Australian animals. Some of these auimals are being exported, and their export should be rigidly controlled. I agree with the honourable member for Adelaide that birds which are pests may be freely exported. Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Title: Unknown
text: Yarra) [5.27 a.m.] This is a very suitable hour of the morning for the protest I am about to make against the parsimony of the Government at present in office. Their treatment of some of the most hard working employees in its service is only what one would expect from. a miserable sweater. I refer to the office-cleaners in the employ of the Commonwealth. Those, in this city are paid on a basis calculated on the determination of a Victorian Wages Board, which fixes £ 3 2s. 4d. for a week of forty-four hours. That works out at Is. 5d. per hour. Government do not employ these officecleaners for forty-four hours per week. They employ them for only twenty-four hours a week, and pay them the miserable wage of Is. 5d. per hour or 34s. per week.

Speaker: Mr BOWDEN
Title: Unknown
text: Is this work their only occupation?

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Title: Unknown
text: It is. They have no opportunity to engage in any other occupation. Most of them are widows who have lost their breadwinners. They leave home about 5 o'clock in the morning to do office cleaning, and return to their homes to get the.ir children ready for school. They return again in the afternoon after office hours. get twenty-four hours' work week, and are paid at the rate of Is. 5d. per hour. Under the determination of the Victorian Wages Board, if they were employed for only twenty-two hours per week, they would have to be paid at the rate of Is. l i d . per hour. In order to avoid the necessity of paying these people casual rates, the Government employs them for two hours over the minimum, and at the rate of Is. 5d. per hour. It should not require any stressing of the matter to convince the Minister that this is not fair treatment for these women. There are not many of those women, and the sum that would be involved in the suggested increase would not be great. The Government should be a little more just to those who are probably the lowest paid workers in its employ.

Title: Unknown
text: Hav e they not to supply some of the cleaning material they use?

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Title: Unknown
text: Possibly; but no complaint on that score has been made to me. No one will deny that these women are badly paid. Representations have been made by their union.

Title: Unknown
text: I have no recollection of any such representations since I have been in office.

Title: Unknown
text: I understand that representation's have been made to the Department, and that the complainants have received no satisfaction. There are plenty of private employers who' would not take such a paltry advantage of their employees as the Government are taking of the women office-cleaners.

Speaker: Mr R GREEN
Title: Unknown
text: Richmond) [5.32 a.m.] - I congratulate the Minister for Works upon the effort he has made in the House and in his Department to have, this Parliament removed to Canberra as soon as possible. Even before a motion had been carried in the House, at the instance of the honourable member for Dalley (Mr Mahony), the Minister had given proof of his bona fide intention to do what lay in his power to have the Constitutional provision regarding the They Federal Capital honored. This House per has now definitely resolved that the Goveirnor-General shall be asked to convene the next Parliament at Canberra. I am sorry that there is not on the Estimates-a small amount for the survey, or some other preliminary work, in connection with the proposed railway between Kyogle and Brisbane. This line has been discussed between Commonwealth and State Ministers as part of the scheme for the unification of gauges. Recently the Minister for Works, whom I commend for endeavouring, by travel, to learn first-hand Australia's requirements, made a trip through Southern Queensland and the Kyogle district, covering a portion of the proposed route. He saw some of the magnificent country that a railway would open up, and the terrible isolation of the settlers there, and he expressed surprise that such a fine territory should, be absolutely undeveloped. He was already strongly predisposed towards the line, and his trip influenced him further in its favour. The Treasurer (Dr Earie Page) and the Postmaster-Genera] (Mr Gibson), who accompanied him, were equally favourably impressed. I am disappointed, therefore, that there is not a sum on the Estimates to indicate that the construction of the line is to be proceeded with. I know that the Minister for Works is quite in earnest in his advocacy of the railway, but the five State Governments of the mainland are concerned in the question of cost. The Kyogle-Brisbane line is not to be merely a district utility; it is to be portion of a greatscheme affecting the whole Commonwealth in respect of defence and transcontinental communication. The States of New South Wales and Queensland have already expressed their approval of the line, but I should like to know more concerning the attitude of other States, particularly South Australia, the . Premier of which, Sir Henry Barwell, appears to be- a most benighted individual, with a very limited conception of the national interests. I quite ' understand that the absence of any reference to the Hay-Port Augusta line is due to the difference of opinion amongst the State Premiers, again headed by Sir Henry Barwell. The Minister for Works and Railways was mainly responsible for the main roads development scheme, which was recently approved by the House. I congratulate him upon that proposal, because the expenditure involved will be of inestimable benefit to country districts. Roads, particularly those in the country, play a peculiar part in our national life. They are free to all. Whereas one may travel by trains only at such times as are suitable to the general community or the Department, the road is Open to anybody at any time. And all may travel on it as they please-in Rolls-Royce motor car, on horse, on a bicycle, or on foot. Roads make travel more convenient, and transport' easier and more rapid. They are necessary, not only as great highways between cities, but also as the arteries of industry in the country, carrying produce from outlying hamlets to the towns and goods from the town shops to the settlers. A good road means less freighting, a saving of time, and an increase of comfort. Mr It. Green. Anything that will add to the comfort and prosperity of the people should be strongly supported by honourable members, and roads should be recognised as of great assistance to pioneers in the back-blocks, who are fighting so hard to make this country the success it should be. As a general rule, the city gets all the plums in the form of expenditure, but the grant for new roads is an exception. The roads are not to be built in the cities, but are to be developmental in character, and to link up great country districts. I again congratulate the Minister for Works and Railways on the service he is rendering the Commonwealth. Mr C. RILEY (Cook) [5.45 a.m.] I direct the attention of the Minister for Works and Railways to the necessity of providing adequate accommodation for workmen engaged at the Federal Capital site. During the last two months the weather has been anything but pleasant, and a number of cases of influenza has been reported. Most of the men are housed in old military huts or .canvas .tents, and therefore their living , conditions are anything but satisfactory. If we are in earnest in connection with the construction of Parliament House, the hostel, and other public buildings, it will be necessary to insure an adequate supply of skilled labour. To do this it is essential that suitable accommodation should, be available, not only for the workmen, but also - for their wives and children. . The contractor for the hostel has made the suggestion that suitable' temporary weatherboard dwellings of three or four rooms could be erected quite handy to where building operations were being carried out for about £180 each. These would serve the workmen during the period of a capital construction, and they could afterwards be removed. If this suggestion were adopted, the Government would not be embarrassed in their building operations by a scarcity of suitable* labour. I know that scores of expert tradesmen, bricklayers, carpenters, and other artisans would be prepared to go to Canberra and take up work there if they could depend upon having accommodation for their wives and children. This proposal is a practical suggestion, and well worthy of the Minister's earnest attention. The honourable mernber for Yarra- (Mr . Scullin) mentioned that the women cleaners in the employ of the AVorks and Railways and Postmaster-General's Departments were not receiving fair treatment. Women employees in Commonwealth Departments who are widows, and have children, should receive the same consideration as male employees with children dependent upon them, and receive the benefit of child endowment. . In the Governor General's establish-, ment, on page 271, there appears an iteni - £ 4 0 0 for telephones at, I presume, the Melbourne and Sydney Government Houses. There seems to be something wrong. Is it that the servants' rooms, the garage, and outhouses are connected by telephones ? If the pruning, knife is to be applied to employees in the Public Service, we should also insist upon proper economy being observed in the Governor General's establishments. The sum could very well .be cut in half. The Governor General is paid £10,000 per year, and he should be expected to pay his own telephone bills. Honourable members are expected to have telephone connection from their residences, and to pay the ground rental and for all originating calls. It is not fair that the taxpayer should be saddled with this huge amount in respect of the Governor General's telephone services. There is also an item for china and glass at the Governor General's establishments. This, too, is quite unnecessary. If , through any. carelessness, breakages occur in the Governor General's household, the taxpayer should not be called upon to replace the broken articles. Another item, is £100 for fittings and furniture. Last year the expenditure under this heading was £ 1 9 6 , making the total for the two years just under £ 3 0 0 . We are entitled to some explanation from the i Minister. Does this expenditure represent the removal of fittings or cupboards to suit the likes or dislikes of some of the Governor General's household? One other item, £2,550, is for non-recurring works at Melbourne and Sydney Government Houses. What' does this mean ? explanation should be given. W it h regard to the Federal members' room at the Commonwealth Offices, Sydindeed, ney, I desire to bring under the notice the Minister the case of the attendant, and to make ap appeal on his behalf. This officer is most discreet and polite to the numerous callers seeking interviews with honourable members, and is, of very great assistance to the twenty-eight members and six senators from New South Wales. He is a returned soldier, and I know that his salary is inadequate. I trust that the Minister will take steps to have this officer's position re-classified, and see what he can do to pay adequately an officer doing such good work.

text: Postmaster-GeneralCorangamite) [6.30 a.m.] - I intended to say something on the Budget in regard to the Post Office Department generally, but I am confined now to the matters dealt with in the Estimates before the Committee. I shall not take up much time, as I know that honourable members desire to speak about post office' and telephone construction. I am very glad that the criticism levelled against the Department I have the As honour to administer - has been very friendly. With regard to telephones, honourable members know that last year we spent something like £2,000,000 on constructional work. I want to pay a  office of Postmaster-General prior to my taking over the administration of the Department. He set out to catch up with some of the arrears of construction, and he went so far as to widen ' the concessions to country districts generally. The present Government propose to further extend the facilities for communication in the country districts. Honourable members will recognise that this is a work of very great magnitude when they remember that we are spending this year some £4,000,000. If we had before us a proposal for the construction of a railway at a cost of £4,000,000 we would hardly expect to spend the money in one year. It is, however, proposed to spend the £4,000,000 on the Post and Telegraph Department's operations during the coming year. That is almost double the amount expended last year. I hope honourable members . will recognise that this is a very big work, and will give a great deal of employment. The expenditure will cover only works that are absolutely necessary, and that represent only a part of the for expenditure of £10,000,000, which will be completed in a future programme of construction for 1924-25. The public seem to think that . it is quite an easy matter to make connexions with the telephone service, but when it is explained that it costs as much per mile to lay down conduits and cables in the capital cities as to lay down a line of railway, it will be seen that it is not an easy matter to make some of the connexions for which people are clamouring today. The arrears are very great. Something 'like 14,000 people are still waiting for connection with the telephone service. Since the present Government came into office we have connected some 3,000 per month, which, I think, is a very great feat. It exceeds anything done by the Post and Telegraph Department before, and is an absolute record. I feel sure that we will shortly be making 4,000 telephone connexions per month, and we must do so if we are to give in a reason' able time the service which people are looking for. Some honourable members opposite have said that most of the money is being expended in city areas, and others have said that most of it is being spent in country areas, so the Department would appear to have struck the happy medium. I propose to explain what is being done in both city and country areas. The references made by the honourable members for Hume  Gabb), and, I think, Kalgoorlie (Mr A. Green) were particularly to the expenditure on buildings, and not so much to the amount of £2,980,000 which appeared in the Loan Estimates for telephones and telegraph works. What we are proposing to spend is £3,200,000 on telephones and telegraphs; £729,366 on buildings, and £82,400 on sites. In 1922-23 we spent £2,000,000 on telephone and telegraph works, and £182,818 on buildings. The allocation of the £3,200,000 proposed to be expended this year is as follows:New South Wales £645,300 in metropolitan areas, and £701,200 in country areas, or a total of £1,346,500. In Victoria, £444,400 in metropolitan areas, and £326,900 in,country areas, or a total of £771,300. In Queensland, £159,500 in metropolitan areas, and 322,600 in country areas, total £482,100. In South Australia, £185,700 in metropolitan areas and £202,500 in country areas, total £338,200. In Western Australia, £56,100 in metropolitan areas and £132,600 in country areas, total £188,700. In Tasmania, £31,000 in metropolitan areas and £42,200 in country areas, total £73,200. These figures give a grand total of £1,472,000 for metropolitan areas, and £1,728,000 for country areas; 46 per cent, of the total expenditure will be in the metropolitan areas, and 54 per cent, in the country districts. I should say that this does not represent the whole of the money being expended in country districts for the reason that it is necessary to dismantle a good deal of work in city areas, and many switch boards, conduits and cables are transferred from city to country areas. The country districts get the benefit of this dismantled material with little cost to them. Taking that into consideration the actual amount Mr Oibsun, which is to be expended in the country districts will be much more than the figures I have just given.

text: Yes , mostly. The material is simply removed to country districts. Honourable members will understand that the capacity of conduits and cables in the capital cities is in some cases soon outgrown by the. increased traffic and the dismantled' material is quite useful for the country districts. With regard to cable material there has been a great deal of difficulty in the past in getting this material. In city areas, very many applications for telephones have been outstanding for a very long time. It is a very difficult matter indeed because of the lack of cables to make the connexions required. I have explained that the cost of laying down conduits and cables of 1,000 pairs of wires amounts to over £5,000 per mile, and many would be subscribers must remain without connexions until such time as conduits are laid down, and the cable arrives from overseas. When we are in a position to do so, we shall, instead of connecting one subscriber, connect hundreds, or even a thousand, by a single cable. I must confess that the telephone system in the capital cities is very bad indeed, and the position in Sydney is probably worse tban in any of the other capital cities of Australia. There the junction lines between the exchanges are not sufficient for the number of persons who want connexions between them. There" are only fifty junction lines for 500 people,- and if more than fifty wish to be connected at one time, the whole automatic exchange is thrown out of order. As a result we are today really spoiling the valuable machinery contained in the exchanges. We are making an effort to have additional junction lines placed in position at the earliest date. We are trying to give the community as soon as possible the service which should be given in the capital cities ' as well as in the country districts. In the five months since the present Government took office, an average of 3,000 subscribers per month has been connected, and half of those are in country districts. Speaker: Mr SCUIXIN
Title: Unknown
text: How long will i before all the applicants in big cities like Melbourne are connected? Mr GIBSON" - We hope that most of them will be connected in twelve months. We are laying down many conduits and cables with 1,000 pair wires in each, so that thousands of subscribers can be readily connected in a week or a fortnight after the exchanges are ready. In the past we have had a great difficulty in getting a supply of switchboards and cables, but at the present time orders are coming forward very well. The whole of the cable has been coming from England, but the Department has given a contract to an Australian f i r m to manufacture cable in the coming year. The whole of the orders for copper wire, totalling 50,000 or 60,000 miles, have been placed with an Australian firm. As indicating the progress that is being made and the revenue that is flowing into the telephone service, I may in for m the Committee that the revenue from calls in July, 1922, was £278,794, and in July, 1923, £302,283, representing an increase of £23,489. Similar figures could be quoted for every other month, and I 'feel sure that, if the Department were able to give prompter connection on the telephones, the business would be increased very largely. The new work to be put in hand will mean the employment of very many temporary hands. At the present time, 2,655 returned soldiers are employed on telephone and telegraph works, and we propose to engage another 700 to help in carrying out the 1923-24 programme. Some of the concessions made to the public in regard to telephone services were stated in the Budget speech. In future, we propose to base trunk-line charges on direct mileage instead of route mileage. Very many country districts have lines running parallel, with in 10 or 1.5 miles, but the route mileage travelled by the telephone message may be 60 miles. B y adopting the direct mileage instead of the route mileage, we are placing country districts on exactly the same footing as the cities. Every country district subscriber will be able, without paying a trunk-line fee, to communicate within a 5-mile radius of the exchange to which he is connected. Country subscribers will thus be in the same position as if they were connected with a city exchange. t be rental for the use of Government poles has been reduced from 10s. per mile to 5s. per mile for metallic circuit, or 2s. 6d. per mile per wire, and for lines constructed wholly by the Department from £ 2 to 30s. per mile; Formerly subscribers in country districts were asked to pay two years' rental in advance, while the city subscriber was asked for only one year's rental. I have directed that the city and country subscribers shall be placed on the same basis. If it is safe to accept one year's rental from a city subscriber, it should be equally safe to accept it from a man in the country. In the city, up to £65 per subscriber can be expended in providing a subscriber's line, but only £21 could be expended in the country. Henceforth, up to £65 may be spent on a country subscriber's line. A furthe r disability imposed on the country subscriber was that, even though there, were two or three applicants in a certain district, the Department would not erect .a line for more than 2 miles from the exchange. In future, if four or five people in ' a district make application to become subscribers, the limitation of £65 per subscriber will apply instead of the distance limitation.

Speaker: Mr HILL
Title: Unknown
text: Does not the country man have to give a seven-years' guarantee? I do not think that prevails in the cities.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: Unknown
text: The guarantee is over and above the £65 per subscriber.

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Title: Unknown
text: Does the Minister mean that if five subscribers to a country exchange make application, the line may be extended a distance of 10 miles?

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: Unknown
text: No . The proposal is to spend £ 6 5 per subscriber, and in this respect the country subscriber will be placed oh exactly the same footing as the subscriber in city areas. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Jackson) referred just now to the length of the poles. The Act does not permit wires being less than 12 feet in height being erected along fences, and less than 18 feet over roads. I intend to introduce an amendment of the Act to enable us to place wires on poles 8 feet high, instead of 12 feet along certain routes. It is not proposed to use these shorter poles in cities or towns, or in places where there are a number of wires, but in the more sparsely populated districts in Western Australia, QueensThe land, and the Northern Territory. In some areas it is absolutely essential that we should erect iron poles. I had an estimate for a line from Camooweal to the present overland telegraph line. The 'cartage of the posts for the line would have cost £20,000., I propose to cut that cost in half by reducing the height of the pole's-.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Title: Unknown
text: Denison) [7.2 a . m . ] In the Postmaster-General's Department there is an item £30,000 for the conveyance of mails between the mainland and Tasmania by certain steamship companies, under contracts with the Department. I should like the Minister to give some information as to when these contracts will expire.' If they have only a short term to run, I suggest the advisability of not renewing them for a lengthy period, because this expenditure of £30,000 would .be an important factor in the profitable working of the Common-, wealth Line of steamers between the mainland and Tasmania. I know that I would not be in order if I referred at length to the necessity for the Commonwealth employing Government steamers in this trade, but, unfortunately, owing to the declaration of urgency in respect of the Estimates, I was deprived of my opportunity to refer to this matter when the Department which controls shipping was under discussion. Once again I enter my protest against this method of doing business. The action of the Government is preventing fair and . reasonable debate on the Estimates. Recently we passed a Bill which contains a provision for the appointment of a Board to take over and control the Commonwealth Line. The Board will have authority to purchase suitable vessels, and if it considered that course desirable, to put Commonwealth vessels on the run between the mainland and Tasmania, in competition with privately-owned ships. This sum of £30,000 now being paid under contract to the various. shipping companies for' the conveyance of mails to and from Tasmania, wil l be a very important factor in the successful running of any Commonwealth steamers that may be put into commission in that trade. Unfortunately, owing to the tactics of the Government, I have been deprived of the chance to have a vote recorded in connection with a. motion for : the appointment of a commission to in quire into and' report upon the advisability of Commonwealth steamers engaging in the trade between the mainland and Hobart. I hope, however, that we may yet have an opportunity of getting a vote, because I am satisfied that a majority of the members were sympathetically interested in the motion. The Commission could do its work within a week, and submit a report to Parliament. I - believe that the Board to be appointed tocontrol Commonwealth shipping will give early attention to this question, and I am satisfied that it will not be long beforeCommonwealth vessels are put on the run between the mainland and Tasmania. In that event, the amount paid under themail contract with privately-owned vessels could be paid as a subsidy to the Commonwealth ships, and be an important factor in their success.

Speaker: Mr LISTER
Title: Unknown
text: E v e r since I have been a member of the House complaints have been raised during the discussion on the Estimates about the insufficiency of thetime allowed to debate the .items of proposed expenditure; but even if the time were extended four-fold, I believe that similar complaints would be made. I - wish to compliment the Postmaster General (Mr Gibson) and the competent staff under his control for the servicesthey are rendering. I have had a good deal to do with the Post and Telegraph Department, which is a governmental activity which comes into, closer touch with the general community than any - other. D u r in g the time. I have been a. member of this House, I have always received the greatest courtesy from postal officials, even down to the messenger boys, and I think it is only right to pay them some small tribute for the efficient service they render. The position held by the Minister has always been regarded as a political grave, but I - am satisfied that if the present Postmaster-General continues his good work it will be a long time before it can again be so regarded. A good deal has been.said concerning thenecessity for providing country districts with the facilities enjoyed by the people in the metropolitan areas, and it is gratifying that the Government have submitted a policy which will materially tend to increase development in the outback country. The Minister will be justified in making inquiries into the n manner in which city telephone cabinets are working, in an endeavour to ascertain why they constantly get out of order. The honourable member for Bass (| Mr Jackson) mentioned this matter a few days ago, and I have lately had a similar experience. The telephones, at railway stations particularly, are frequently out of order, and consequently a good deal of revenue is lost. There is also an insufficient number of telephone cabinets in the metropolitan areas, and revenue is lost for this cause, because people cannot waste time in waiting an opportunity to call subscribers - I was interested to hear the Minister's statement that it is proposed to manufacture cable in Australia. If this work is undertaken, employment will be provided for a large number of our own people. I trust that some of the cable coming forward will be ear-marked for Geelong, where there have been numerous complaints owing to persons being unable to get connected with the exchange. The installation of an additional switchboard at. the Geelong, Post Office is also a pressing need. The existing boards are full, and even if a permanent board is not available, perhaps the Minister will authorize the installation of a temporary board to accommodate 100 subscribers to overcome the present difficulty. Improvement should be made in the accommodation provided for the Geelong telephone attendants. The constant clicking of the apparatus must be very irritating to operators. I also understand that the temperature of the room in which they work has to be regulated, and that moist air, which would interfere with the delicate mechanism, must not be admitted. It is intended, I believe, to provide additional facilities for the telephone attendants in a room adjoining that which they now occupy, and I trust that provision will be made in this direction at an early date. The traffic on the trunk line between Geelong and Ballarat is frequently congested, and at times there is difficulty in establishing communication between the two pl'aces. The difficulty could be overcome by the construction of a line 8 miles in length from Fyansford to Murgheboluc, and I am glad to learn that this work which is now contemplated may soon be authorized. As the revenue of the Department has been buoyant, those,in charge of allowance post-offices might well be granted an additional allowance, as the amounts received in some cases are too small. I am sorry that a "Werribee mail delivery service on the northern side of the railway line has not been arranged, and that the Department has not complied with the request of the Albion Ratepayers Association to place a letter-box on the Albion railway station. Naturally, all the work requiring attention in my electorate has not been done, but it is pleasing to know that attention has been given to many of the requests I have submitted.

Speaker: Mr CHARLTON
Title: Unknown
text: Hunter) [7.30 a.m.] - I wish to refer briefly to the development of the wireless broad-casting system, which is a matter that should be given careful consideration by honourable members on account of its importance to our country districts. An agitation has been going on for some time for the provision of wireless broadcasting facilities. A deputation met the Postmaster-General recently, and in consequence a number of regulations have been framed which are on the. table of the House at present. Unless objection is taken to them by 15th August, they will become law and will have all the force of'an Act of Parliament. I have 'nothing to say i agains.t the action of the Postmaster General in endeavouring to establish this system.' If it is successful it will be a great boon to people who live in the more remote parts of the country. It will increase the pleasure of life to them, and will enable them to obtain information of important matters which occur in the capital cities or in other parts of Australia. Buf I have received several letters which seem to indicate that the regulations are not altogether satisfactory.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: Unknown
text: Can the honourable member tell me from whom he received the letters ?

Speaker: Mr CHARLTON
Title: Unknown
text: On e came from the Wireless DevelopmentAssociation of Victoria, 323 Flinders-street, Melbourne;. another from Mr John Payne, editor of the Australasian Wireless Review, 143 Avoca-street, Randwick, Sydney; and another from Mr C. W. Norris, 346 Post Office-place, Melbourne. In the .opinion offchewriters the regulations are framed differently from those which operate in New Zealand, Great Britain, and America. They have requested me to take action to prevent the regulations from becoming law. I told them that I could not do that, as the time for which Parliament would be sitting would not permit it. But I promised that I would take the first opportunity to bring the matter under the notice of the Postmaster-General. I understand that the Minister framed these regulations after a conference was held, and I - suppose, therefore, that he has some justification for them. We should make these facilities available as far as possible to all the people in the out-back settlements, and not only to the wealthier classes. If we can use this means to bring a little sunshine into the lives of the folk out-back we should do it. Our people should not be in a position any less advantageous than that of the people of Great Britain or other parts of the British Dominions. The letter from the Wireless Development Association of Victoria reads323 Flinders-street, Melbourne. Dear Sir, We received your letter this morning, and have much pleasure in forwarding another copy of the cuttings. We believe that today is the last day. on which a protest can be lodged in , the House on the Wireless Bill this session. While the Postmaster-General states that there was no opposition at the time of the conference, we would like to point out that at the conference the public was not represented, and it is the public's interest that we wish to protect. The only interests that have been protected by the present regulations are any broadcasting station which might start, and there is no .limit in the fees that they may demand from the public for their service. event of more tlian one broadcasting station starting and charging for services, the public will have "to pay for both 'broadcasting stations if they desire to listen to both, and so the ordinary working man will be debarred from listening in . This is not so in New Zealand, America, England, South America, and Europe, and' why should Australia be placed in this position ? You will also notice that Tjroadcasting stations have the monopoly for five . years, which means that we are held up by them for five years. If the regulations are amended, they uu-doubtedly will claim compensation against the Government - '„ interested We would be pleased to give you any other help in this matter. Yours faithfully, Mr Charlton. According to that letter certain companies are to be given a monopoly for five years. 1 ° Mr GiBSON.^That is not so.

Speaker: Mr CHARLTON
Title: Unknown
text: I am pleased to hear that. The writer of that letter points out that if such a monopoly were given, and subsequently it was found necessary to alter the agreement in the public interests, the companies which had been granted a monopoly would claim compensation. This association forwarded a copy of a letter from C. W. Norris, of Norris & Skelly, 346 Post Office-place, Melbourne, July 1923. It reads: " BROADCASTING OR THE SEALED BOX? " To the Editor, Electrical Times. Sir, Now that the recent Conference called by ihe Minister (Mr Gibson, P.M.G.) is over and the discussion has been published, the majority (which have just discovered that there has been a conference affecting their business as electrical traders) on hearing the result stand aghast! While we all agree that broadcasting must be governed, and, possibly, subsidized-in small c populated areas such as Australia - wha t we cannot understand is that the Australian Government has agreed to demand that, be9th August, 1923. fore the public can even purchase a receiving set, they must pay a - fee to one broadcasting station-that is, after paying 10s. for a licencethen they are allowed to purchase a sealed box. If they do not like the particular station for which they have already paid their money, then back they go with their sealed box to their dealer and pay a small fee to have same altered to another wave length; then it will be necessary to pay a fee to this broadcasting station, and they are allowed to take home their sealed box again, and so on and so on. Do you honestly think the public will do this ? Mr Gibson stated to myself and others, while on a deputation of protest, that it will 'be just like ui book-lending library-if you don't like In the one you just go to another. Yes, but remember that you pay and you can choose at random what book you want, but not so with the sealed box. I would suggest that, as the Government is so good as to sponsor the broadcasting companies which will have every possibility of becoming monopolies, as in England, that they do the job properly here, as suggested below:(1) Raise the licence fee to £ 3 3s. per annum. (2) Genuine experimenters be protected as at present,- and charged 10s. per annum. (3) Appoint a Board, consisting of representatives of the Radio Department, broadcasting companies, traders, press and others directly in broadcasting (these to be paid a small fee, if any at all), to control-broadcasting. (4) Moneys received in fees to be allotted as follows :-Fiv e shillings of each to go to the Radio Department for the control and superC. W . CHUM , Treasurer. vision of wireless, which will include strict supervision by their officers (heavy penalties for breaches), the balance to be paid into a fund to subsidize broadcasting. (5) The Board to accept programmes, which will include entertainments, public notices, weather reports, & c , also times for services. Then call tenders for thU service, successful tenders to be under bond to maintain the programmes. (6) One subsidized broadcasting station to be allotted to each capital city. More as funds from fees permit for other centres. (7) That the licences be issued to companies or firms desirous of broadcasting on payment of a fee, say £20, and placing a bond to maintain small service for one year, advertisements to be strictly limited, no charge whatever to public for the service, but would be on any wave length available, and under strict Radio Department's regulations. (8) That all receiving sets bought complete or made up of parts can be capable of receiving on any. wave lengths. (9) All dealers in wireless apparatus to be licensed and under penalties for supplying - apparatus to others than holders of Government licences. (10) Licences to be obtained at post-offices or licensed dealers. Then broadcasting will have a chance to be on the proper lines, the public having six subsidized high-power stations at their service and a number of other stations supplied by firms, &c. (as in USA. at present}, but properly supervised here, all for the sum of £ 3 3s. per annum. Just you calculate the money available by subscribers in each capital city, which would be at least £10,000 per State. Then the Minister, Mr Gibson, could see his' dream come true-Australi a the only country in the world running broadcasting on proper lines.

Speaker: Mr CHARLTON
Title: Unknown
text: The letter I received from Mr John Payne, editor of the Australasian Wireless Review, of Sydney, under date 6th August, is the following:Wireless is one of the most revolutionary things that has happened in the century from the educational point of view, and from our point of view as Labour men we should do all in our power to further the coming of the benefits'of this science into the homes to add brightness and happiness. In the Old Country the wharfie has his little set, and listens in at night with his family. It keeps him at home, and the home is the brighter and happier for it . There any one can have a radio receiving set to cover any wave length, and this means that he can listen into all kinds of concerts from all over the place. In New Zealand splendid regulations have been gazetted, and any one there can have a receiver which will receive any wave length, and concerts are heard in different places from the North Cape to the Bluff, the annual licence fee being only 5s. In England the listener-into radio concerts, as they are called, pays £1 per year, 10s. of which goes to the Broadcasting Company, a company formed to rendei; radio service tlu'oughout Great Britain. In addition, amateurs send music. So far, a fee of only £ 1 . An English radio man can listen to' any concert for that inclusive sum. In America there is absolutefreedom, as only an annual licence fee is charged by the Government of a nominal amount, and the big firms broadcast free for the purpose of advertisement mainly. Our regulations have just been gazetted, as you will be aware, and they contain some of the most damnable and restrictive provisions on the radio concert listener it is possible to conceive. 1I have quoted sufficient to show that there is some dissatisfaction. The people which have corresponded with me understand the business. I hope that the Postmaster-General will see his way to suspend its operation until he has made further inquiries. I have personally no doubt that he has taken every care in the matter, but in the initiation of these things some little mistakes are likely to occur. I agree with the honourable gentleman that it would be unwise to hold up the matter for any great length of time. The system should be introduced as quickly as possible. We should encourage companies to start radio services to give the people the benefit of them. I believe that advantage will be taken of the system by big business companies in the different cities to communicate information concerning their business to their customers. I believe it will he beneficial in many ways.' It is one of the great scientific developments of the last few years, and we should see that it is installed here. I realise that it would be futile to table an objection to the regulation at this stage, because it would be too late. This concerns people in the country districts.proa little bably more than people in the city. In the cities people can go to places of amusement every night, but the residents of country districts scarcely ever hear a concert, and cannot get in touch with the news of the outside world. The installation of theradio services should assist to make the lives of country residents happier than they are today, and 'help them to spend their winter evenings more pleasantly than they can do now. I have been supplied with the regulations which it is desired to have.amended, but it is unnecessary torefer to them here. Those who have communicated with me assure me that their one object in the matter is to make the radio service a cess. I leave the subject at that. I am sure the Postmaster-General will give consideration to the representation I made.  I want - to compliment the Postmaster General upon the very concise way in which he presented his Department's programme. It is gratifying to honourable members who receive so many communications concerning postal .matters to know that every year the Post and Telegraph Department is modernizing as well as liberalizing its ideas. The fact becoming prevalent - that the Department is a public utility, and not merely a money-making concern. The expenditure upon it in the different States should not be on a per capita basis. When the Government recently proposed the appropriation of £500,000 for main roads development, they decided that it would be wrong to allocate the vote to - the different States on a per capita basis, because it was obvious that the States in most need of the grant were those with the greater areas. The Government allocated a portion of the £500,000 on the per capita basis, and the balance on an area basis. I was pleased to learn the distribution which the Postmaster-General proposes for this year's expenditure in metropolitan and country areas. His advisers in Western Australia may not have properly - estimated the amount which should be spent in that State. They failed to do so last year under Mr state Poynton's regime, and, if that is the case this year, they will have to apply later on for increased expenditure. The Minister has admitted that he scarcely knows how to get through his programme and spend £4,000,000 in the year effectively. The honourable gentleman will find useful and proper ways of expending the money in Western Australia. I wish to say in the kindliest manner that Western Australia-and I dare say the same thing applies to Tasmania and Queensland-suffer s greatly because of distance from the centre of things in Melbourne. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Lister) was able to refer* the Minister to post-boxes in this street and that street in Geelong, but we cannot do that kind of thing in Western Australia. I hope that the Postmaster-General will , take advantage of the earliest opportunity sucto visit the various States, and that he will especially visit Western Australia. He will find that development is going on have in that State. The State Government is trying to effect the settlement of immigrants on the land. The Commonwealth Government is paying part of the interest on the expenditure of a lot of money in that State for the purpose, and settlement is spreading rapidly into large new areas. We have been told many times in this chamber that if a block of land is put to the ballot in some of the States there will be 500 or 600 applicants for it . That is is not the case in Western Australia. Although it may cost £5,000 per mile to lay cables in the cities, 100 miles might be laid for that money in Western Australia. I hope that during the recess the Postmaster-General will devote as much time as possible to visiting the various States in order to make himself acquainted with local conditions. The Postmaster-General, no matter who he is, must work largely through Deputies. Some Postmasters-General in the past have imposed very restrictive conditions. Officials' of the - Department have been brought up under them, and have got into a groove. They want to be on the safe side, bust the Postmaster-General should let them know that regulations must be liberally interpreted. I hope the Postmaster-General, when he visits Western Australia, will not stay there for only a day or two.

For instance, mail services in country districts were cut down from three to two a week, and in order to get back the old service the people are asked to dip their hands into their pockets to pay a subsidy. One town in a grazing district used to get three mail deliveries a week; the service was cut down to two mails a week, and the residents were informed that if they wished to restore the three-days-a-week service they must pay £70 per annum towards the additional cost. text: I do not think it would be necessary to make any increases. On the contrary, the suburban rate might be reduced to 6d., at which it previously stood. The facilities for lodging lettergrams should also be extended. These are now accepted only at the head office. Why should they not be accepted at every suburban office, so that residents of the suburbs might enjoy the same facilities in this respect as people in the cities? They are handed in as deferred telegrams, and despatched whenever a clear line is available. In some offices the slack period is in the middle of the day; in others, it is in-' the afternoon. As suburban offices close at 6 p.m., this facility could very easily be granted. 1 also desire to urge the establishment of an exchange at Lakemba. I do not wish to encroach upon the electorate of the honourable member for Reid (Mr Coleman), but the people on the Belmore . railway line are united in their desire for this exchange. In the Canterbury municipality alone there are nearly 50,000 ratepayers, and they are unable to get a telephone exchange, and along the Belmore line there are approximately 1,000 subscribers, and there would be more if the exchange were provided. An extra rate is charged to these people because they live more than a certain distance from the Ashfield, Burwood, and Homebush Exchanges. Such treatment of people in a thickly populated area is not fair, and, moreover, the absence of an exchange is not economical for the Department. If an exchange were provided money could be saved, and subscribers given much more efficient service. I hope, also, that the Minister will give further consideration to the request for the establishment of a post-office at Hurlstone Park. This office is very much needed in the interests of a thickly populated area.*  [10.15 a.m.] - I wish to bring under the notice 'of the Postmaster-General the miserable remuneration given to those people who run allowance post-offices in the country. Those in control of semi official offices complain bitterly of what happens to them when they build up an office to official status. They suddenly find themselves - without a job. kind of treatment is unfair to people who are in charge of semi-official offices, and discourages them from putting forward their best efforts in the interests of. the Department and the public. I bring the matter under the notice of the Postmaster-General in the hope that he will do something to see that men who give their time and energy to the building up of these offices will not be thrown out of employment because of their success. I have received several complaints of this character. Then there are the allowance offices. I know the stereotyped answer of the Department to requests for increased allowances to the persons in charge of these offices. It is pointed out that allowance post-offices are given only to persons who have another business. There are many places, particularly small places out-back, where it is not possible to run any other' business in conjunction with an allowance office. They have to be at the beck and call of the public, not only during ordinary office hours, but at all times. A huge institution like the Post Office, which is showing a large profit, should do something to improve the conditions of these people. While I am thankful for small mercies, and admit that the Postmaster-General is doing something to meet the position, there is still a grievance in country districts that the greater proportion of the money voted for new works is spent in city areas. Last year £58,462 was spent in the country in New South Wales as against £244,429 in the-city areas. A sum of £1,400 was to have been expended on a new building at Wagga. The existing post-office building is a disgrace to such a place, which is one of the best towns between Sydney and Melbourne. In the Estimates this year a sum of only £500 is provided. The postmaster is compelled to live in. a hotel, where he cannot afford to keep his wife and family, and because of the want of quarters they have to live in Sydney.
