The definition section of the War Pensions Act states that " dependants" includes " the parents of any such person who are, at any time after the occurrence of the event resulting in his death, without adequate means of support." Section 2 makes a pension payable on the death of a soldier provided that(a) A claim for payment of a pension in accordance with this Act is made(i) in case of the death of a member of the Forces-by a dependant not more than lic notification by-the Minister in theGazette of the death of the member, except in the case of parents whothough not dependent upon the earnings of the member at the time of his death are at any time without adequate means of support. Let me .bring under the notice of honourable members one t>f many instances. The only' son in a family, went to the'war and was killed. At that time the parents were' in a sound position. They were supposed to be wealthy, and no application whatever was made for a. pension. Later on the father died and. his estate was found to be insolvent. The mother was lef t with a little over garding what Parliament - desires. £1,000, which today has diminished £900. I advised her . to apply for a war pension, and she did so, but was told that one could . not be granted to her; but that had her husband died within three years of liament, her boy, she could have obtained one, even though she had an income of £1,000 a year. He r income is £40 a year. She was formerly in good and reasonable conditions of livingcircumstances, and is about fifty-seven or fifty-eight years of age. The Departadoption ment said to her, " We cannot give a pension while you have the money. additional Spend the money, and then come to us, when we shall be able to give you a sion." According to the Commissioner she has to become a pauper before she eligible for a pension. I - have asked Department to define what it means by " adequate means of support."- The Act is quite clear in its intention that person who is without adequate means of support at any time after the death of his son while on active service, may, although perhaps not dependent upon him at the time of his death, apply for a pension. how carelessly the question has been thought out, I may instance a statement by a Commissioner, who said to me, ' " Have you ever heard of a person being arrested for not having adequate of support, although he had £100 in his pocket?" People are arrested, not for not having " adequate means of supa.m.] port,", but for not having " visible means of support." The Department contends that a person who possesses £100 is closed. or over does not come within the definiportant tion of the section. I would go so far to say that no person should receive - pension if be was in receipt of more a certain sum. If a person was in receipt of, say, £150 a year, the Commissioners would be justified in saying that he' adequate means of support, but the, the greatest importance. woman to whom I have referred, who has an income of only £ 4 0 a year, not adequate means of support. I have advised her not to follow the advice the Commissioners and spend her money. The Treasurer (D r Page) is full y aware of. the position. In other circumstances I would have proposed a reduction of the item, not with a view to embarrassing the Gothat vernment, but to get Parliament press to the Commissioners an opinion reI to content myself, however, with bringing the matter under the notice of honourable members, so that pressure may be brought to bear upon the Commissioners to induce them to carry out the intention of Parwhich was that if , in the opinion of the Commissioners, a person had not adequate means of support-that is, a about yearly income which would provide fair : a pension should be granted. The of the suggestion would, I " you admit, involve the Government in expenditure. There are other instances similar to those I have pencited. I know of an engineer who went to the front with his son. The son was is killed, and the engineer died' and lef t the' only £800 worth of life assurance policies to his wife. She applied for a pen-, sion and was told that she had adequate any means of support. Parliament, when it passed the Act,. did not intend that the possession of that small amount of ready money should be regarded as " adequate means of support." I am not asking for anything new, but merely for what ParTo show liament deliberately placed' in an Act . The action of the Commissioners is con-, trary to the intentions of Parliament, and is wholly unjust. I leave the matter there, hoping that the Government and means, Parliament will take action later.

Title: Unknown
text: I appreciate the fact that an amending Act is promised; but it may or may not be discussed. The question might very advantageously, and very properly, have been opened up on the discussion of the Estimates. I say no more than that for the present, but I wish to lose no opportunity to deal with the subject. In the electorate which I have the honour to represent there is a very large number of occupants of War Service Homes, and they have many just complaints. I have been asked to introduce a deputation next week in connection with the matter, which, as every one knows, is a ,most complicated one. There is scarcely a member of Parliament who does not desire to bring individual cases under notice. A very informative address on the question of national health was given in this Committee by the honourable member for Darling (Mr Blakeley), and I venture to express regret that no representative of the Ministry has made any statement upon a subject of such importance. Although we labour under many disadvantages in having this Government," we have an advantage in the fact that it includes as Treasurer an eminent medical man. I am quite prepared to concede that much. He is a ' man who, in the pursuit of his profession, has rendered very distinguished services to the community. I make that declaration apart from political considerations. I suggest that it would have been appropriate if Parliament had had the advantage of his advice and assistance in connection with the question of health. One phase of health is the much-debated Spahlinger treatment for tuberculosis. I am very much interested in that, and in the meagre newspaper reports regarding the extent to which it is being tested. At times I have felt deep disappointment by reason of the fact that the Government was apparently regarding this alleged cure lukewarmly, if not indifferently. Such an attitude, is not fair to the people of the Commonwealth. Tuberculosis is a dread disease, and if, by the expenditure of a few thousand pounds-nay , I would say millions of pounds-w e could introduce a reliable corrective to the dread bacillus, we would be spending money wisely, and in a direction that would have the support of every member of Parliament. I can merely "mention those twoor three matters, and there are a host of others which might Avell have been discussed under the same heading had timepermitted. I want to allow other honourable members a few minutes for discussion before the time limit is reached. I conclude, as I began, with a public protest against the way in which the Estimates .have been handled and Parliament has been treated by the Government.

Speaker: Dr EARLE PAGE
Title: Unknown
text: Cowper-Trea surer) [11.31] - I wish to state very plainly. the Government's attitude on the question of health. I listened very attentively to the able speech delivered the other day by the honourable member for Darling (Mr Blakeley). The subject on which he spoke should be ventilated much more than it is. His speech was a distinct contribution to the discussion of national health, and that discussion might easily be added to from many other sources. The Government is anxious, and has shown itself very desirous, of proceeding with a national health policy, but its activities are very much hampered by the fact that it cannot bring the States into line. At the Premiers' Conference the Government put forward proposals, and pressed the States very hard, to assist us with expert advice in forming a Royal Commission to investigate the whole question, and define definitely the spheres of the Commonwealth Government, the State Governments, and the municipal authorities. The most we could do was to obtain'the consent of the States to their public health officers discussing the matter with the ' Commonwealth health officer, after which the States would consider the representations made by those oflicers. The Government has endeavoured to arrange that conference. I have repeatedly urged that it should be held, but we have not been able to arrange it up to the present. As soon as that conference takes place I am hopeful that we shall be able to have a Royal Commission, so that by this time next year we shall be able to adopt a definite line of action, and go straight ahead with a national health policy. This should lead not only to a discussion of the health of the community, but also to the adoption of measures to prevent the spread of disease, which, as was shown by the late war, can be done on a big scale. The difficulty we have had with the States explains why the proposed vote is almost the same as that for last year. Regarding tuberculosis and the possibility of discovering a cure, the Govern- merit's position is quite plain. could see with any certainty a definite cure for that disease, or any process that would markedly alleviate and lessen the effects of it in the community, it would pay almost any price, and think that price cheap, to secure such a benefit. The Government is quite in the dark regarding the merits of the Spahlinger cure. We have sent representatives abroad, but they have not been able to obtain the information we desire. is nob the Government's duty to "buy a pig in" a poke."

Title: Unknown
text: That is a matmately ter which could' be discussed w committee; as I have said I do not think we are justified in discussing such cases on the floor of the House, and thus placing on record facts which might be read by the descendants of these men. No attempt whatever has been made to diminish the war pensions, nor has there been any falling-away in the sympathy which 0 is extended to the recipients. Many of these men areextremely ill , and some of them, unfortunately, die. That is one" way, of course, in which the total expen- " diture tends to diminish. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Charlton) referred If it to the necessity for medical treatment for embarrassed widows and children. The Government is going into that matter very carefully, and I hope to be able during the next week to suggest to the House any amendment of the Act that may be considered necessary. However, we may be able to accomplish what we desire by means of regulation. The cases of incapacity may be divided into two classes. There is, It in the first instance, the disability which is set down by the Medical Board as 65 per cent, or 70 per cent. It is found that men with 70 per cent, dis- ability who have been a'ccustomed to clerical or other light occupations have not much difficulty in supplementing their pensions. On the other hand, there are those who have been accustomed to msnual labour requiring full health and strength, and they suffer considerable hardship. I hope during next week to present to honourable members some definite proposal to meet these latter cases. The control of the Repatriation Department, mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition, is receiving the careful attention of the Government. It will have been noticed that the appointment of the Repatriation Commission has been renewed - for only jme year, during which, it is hoped, the Government will be able to co-ordinate the Old-age and Invalid Pensions Department and the Pensions Branch of the Repatriation Department. The object is, at first, to enable these to run on parallel lines, with a view to their be complete association. Both staffs are to be housed in the building of the Repatriation Department, and it is hoped ultito effect a considerable saving in it h the the administrative charges. The matter referred to by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Gregory) is one of interpretation of the Act . The patriation Commission take "adequate means of support" to mean some amount of ready money sufficient to prevent absolute necessity. However, the manner in which this Act shall be interpreted and administered must be in accordance with the views and wishes of honourable members. In the short time still available, 1 should be glad to have an expression of opinion from honourable members on the point. My own idea is that a more liberal interpretation should be applied than in the past. The mothers of soldiers should at the very least be placed on the level of old-age and invalid pensioners in this regard. I am now referring to the amount of property and money that an old-age or invalid pensioner may possess without in any way jeopardizing the right to a pension. It is difficultto say what should be the l i m it , and cretionary power must be given to the Commission. At present an old-age pensioner may occupy his own house, or may possess £310 worth of property. amount will be increased in the amending Bill to be introduced.

RILEY (Cook) [11.53 a.m.]. - I protest against the action of the Government in the vote for health purposes. A miserable sum of £15,000 has been provided for the treatment and control of venereal diseases throughout the Commonwealth'. This disease is agrave and serious menace, as it vitally'concerns the national health of Australia. £121,000 set aside for health, £70,000 is devoted to the clerical staff, miscellaneous services, and so on. Fifty thousand pounds is < ear-marked for medical services, laboratory Avork, research, and investigation. That is quite insufficient for this vast continent. In the Estimates for this year the Health Department's, figures for Queensland and the Northern Territory are coupled together, but they are of sufficient importance to be kept separate. I cannot understand the reason for this, although it is perhaps necessary that, from an administrative stand-point,' Queensland be in close touch with the Northern Territory. I have here . an Ordinance concerning the Northern Territory which was issued in March of last year. It deals with the question of venereal disease, and I commend it to honourable members for consideration. contains far-reaching provisions, such as the compulsory notification of venereal disease, and a penalty of £500 or imprisonment for five years for any person Avho marries knowing that he is suffering from venereal disease, yet to some extent Ave are left in the dark. We have not yet had .a statement from the Minister concerning the successful operation of that Ordi nance. There is no amount on the Estimates for cancer research, and no mention of the Spahlinger treatment. If the population were menaced by an invading army, the Government would' act promptly. But they exhibit no haste to combat the ravages of f e l l diseases. It does not concern the Government, evidently, if through its failure to attend to national health, a high percentage of our manhood, in time of war, is certified to be medically unfit. A cure for tuberculosis .would cast a ray of sunshine into the lives of thousands of our returned men. The Government are too busily concerned with the Imperial and Economic Conferences and the matter of Imperia l defence to consider questions relating to the national health; but I trust that next session they will submit concrete proposals to this House. The Treasurer stated that certain things could not be done u n t i l an agreement was reached with the States. What has that to do with national health? It is no reason why the Government should shirk their responsibilities. I cannot understand why the Government, having at their disOut of posal the advice of such medical men as the honourable members for Cowper and Calare, should submit this miserable proposal. I enter my protest against it .
